question: Given that aluminum is recyclable and an aluminum can is made of aluminum, which object used in the experiment can safely be recycled?

content.source_1: In the experiment, a sheet of aluminum foil was used only as a dust cover over a beaker of distilled water; it never contacted any reagents or biological materials.
content.source_2: The lab’s waste manual specifies that clean, uncontaminated aluminum foil may be placed in the metal recycling bin.
content.source_3: During cleanup, a few drops of dilute copper sulfate solution splashed onto the foil cover.
content.source_4: The same waste manual requires any item that has contacted chemical solutions to be disposed of as laboratory waste rather than placed in recycling.
content.source_5: Copper sulfate residues are hazardous to aquatic life, and lab protocols forbid rinsing such residues into ordinary sinks to “clean” an item for recycling.
content.source_6: Aluminum foil is widely recyclable when it is free of residues and compressed into a ball to keep small pieces together.
